{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3384580,"name":"Jared Van Horn","username":"CuteRedpandas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-11T19:35:06.338Z","cooked":"

This past season our shooter was originally designed to run with belts, but after we assembled it all, our belts were way too tight on the shooter and caused way too much resistance so we swapped to chain which worked fine for us. However, I would like to know for the future of how to CAD distances to have the belts be at correct distances to make them work well. I’d also like to know the difference between different belt types and when to use them.

I use the Recalc belt calculator to find the center-center ReCalc, then I subtract 0.02 inches from the number that it gives.

do a cc subtract is the belt run is really close of 0.02 and needs to be high efficiency, but as the belt run becomes longer you should remove the cc subtract. Generally exact works fine

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-05-11T20:14:32.584Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":442,"readers_count":441,"score":118.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466090,"topic_slug":"how-to-design-with-belts","display_username":"Brandon King","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://wcproducts.com/pages/calculator-belt","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Belt Calculator – WestCoast Products","clicks":30}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19708,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2910 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-design-with-belts/466090/5","custom_user_title":"2910 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3384597,"name":"Itai Poran","username":"itaiporan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-11T20:17:05.578Z","cooked":"

There are a couple of approaches to finding the required center distance between pulleys.

One option is to input your pulley sizes and your desired center distance into an online calculator like the WCP belt calculator, and it will show you the available center distances that will fit one of the available for purchase pulleys. If the center distance that it outputs is too far from your targeted distance you may want to play with your pulley sizes to find the perfect pulley length.

Alternatively, if you’re using SolidWorks, you can utilize a special dimension called “Path length.” This feature allows you to sketch the path of the belt directly, simplifying the process. By drawing two circles representing the pitch diameter of the pulleys and connecting them with tangential lines, you essentially create the belt’s path. SolidWorks then generates the belt’s “length” dimension, allowing you to fine-tune the design by adjusting belt and pulley sizes within your CAD software without having to reference the website every time.

If necessary, I can provide example images of the second method to clarify its use. While it may seem complex initially, it offers a straightforward approach that I find preferable to the first method, and makes working with belts in a 2d drawing way more interactive and straightforward.

We normally use a belt calculator like everybody else does, but since our parts are usually made by hand there’s often tolerance. So we often have a belt that’s too loose, or too tight.

But we 3D print our own pulleys. So if we have a problem with the belt being too tight or too loose we can add one tooth or take one off. Sometimes that might result in one pulley having more teeth than the other on the other side. Turns out it really doesn’t make that much difference.

One aspect of belt drive design that is commonly overlooked in FRC is slack-side tensioning or initial tension. It is common not to pretension belt drives at all, nor to have any sort of adjustment capability.

it would be good for a belt drive to use an adjustable idler, or adjustable end pulleys, to achieve slack side tension of at least 10 % of the effective tension. adjustable tension also gives the drive more tolerance in shaft spacing.

Machine Design – 7 Jun 01

Tension in timing-belt drives

A urethane timing belt moves samples into position in this CAD simulation of an automated blood sampling machine.

Belt tension in 3dp pulleys Technical
Looking for opinions from those with more experience. We’ve got a pulley ratio that we think we’d like to tweak and optimize, but we don’t want to remake some parts and adjust center to center distances. There are some pulley ratios that can come pretty close to what we want with similar CC distances, but nothing exact. I’ve gone with options that make the belt a bit loose before and they usually work out, but I’d really like a well tensioned belt here. Has anyone ever tried reprinting a 3dp pu…

I would also look into making your bearing blocks a 3d printed insert instead of directly mounting the bearings in the plate. That way if you need to move the bearing holes something like 0.01" to optimize belt tension you just print a new bearing holder block. (I would give these blocks an indexing feature (e.g. small press in dowel pin and hole on plate, larger 3dprinted holder, etc) and not directly flush mount them to a plate with fasteners).

Personally, I like to use ambcalc.com for finding belt or chain lengths.

We had a belt that was in the middle of a long unsupported shaft for our intake this year, to tension it we printed larger pulleys, I think ended up like 4 teeth larger than calculated.
